hotspots.label: Butterfly Wings
hotspots.fact: A butterfly's wings are covered with tiny scales that create beautiful patterns and colors. These colorful wings help butterflies attract mates and sometimes warn predators to stay away. The yellow and black pattern on this Monarch butterfly's wings tells other animals that it might taste bad!

vocabulary.definition: Tiny, flat pieces that cover a butterfly's wings and give them their patterns and colors.

hotspots.label: Butterfly Antennae
hotspots.fact: Butterflies use their long antennae to sense the world around them, like smelling flowers and finding other butterflies. These special feelers help butterflies locate food and find places to lay their eggs. Without antennae, butterflies wouldn't be able to survive in their habitat!

vocabulary.definition: Long, thin feelers on an insect's head that help it sense smells, tastes, and touch.

hotspots.label: Chrysalis (Cocoon)
hotspots.fact: This empty chrysalis shows where a butterfly went through an amazing change called metamorphosis. Inside the chrysalis, a caterpillar's body completely transformed into a butterfly with wings, legs, and antennae. This is one of the most incredible life cycles in nature!

vocabulary.definition: A big change in an animal's body as it grows, like when a caterpillar becomes a butterfly.

hotspots.label: Ground Habitat
hotspots.fact: Butterflies need safe places like gardens and plants to live, eat, and lay their eggs. This sandy ground is part of the butterfly's habitat where it can rest and find food sources like flowers and nectar. Different habitats support different types of butterflies and other living things.

vocabulary.definition: The place where an animal or plant lives and finds food, water, and shelter.
